issues.description: Constructor signature for StockIngredient is inconsistent across artifacts. The problem statement UML specifies a 3-argument constructor StockIngredient(String, int, int). The solution implements such a 3-argument constructor. However, the template's StockIngredient.java only provides a 4-argument constructor StockIngredient(String, int, int, boolean) (strictValidation). The template's Main (commented example) even calls new StockIngredient("Bacon", 10, 50) using the 3-arg form, which will not compile against the template StockIngredient class. This mismatch will confuse students and may prevent them from compiling or following the intended APIs described in the problem statement.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template API match the problem statement and solution. Add a public 3-argument constructor StockIngredient(String name, int price, int quantity) to the template's StockIngredient class (it may delegate to the existing 4-arg constructor or implement the same validation). Alternatively, provide an overloaded 3-arg constructor and keep the 4-arg one. Ensure the example code in Main and the problem statement use the same constructor signature.

issues.description: Constructor signature for StockIngredient is inconsistent across artifacts. The problem statement UML and the solution implementation expect a three-argument constructor StockIngredient(String, int, int). The template repository's StockIngredient class instead provides a four-argument constructor StockIngredient(String, int, int, boolean strictValidation). This mismatch breaks the clear mapping from the problem description to the template code (and to the provided example usage in Main which calls new StockIngredient("Bacon", 10, 50)). Students following the problem/spec or the solution API will be confused or encounter compilation errors when they try to instantiate StockIngredient as described in the statement or solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template API with the problem statement and solution by providing the three-argument constructor StockIngredient(String name, int price, int quantity). For example, add an overloaded constructor in the template: public StockIngredient(String name, int price, int quantity) { this(name, price, quantity, /*choose default*/ false); } — or remove the extra boolean parameter and revert to the three-argument signature so students can directly instantiate StockIngredient as described in the statement and examples.
